title: Costa Group goes where no company wants to
text:
That shortfall bookbuild is Costa's second test. It will go a long way to determining how the company's shares fare on resumption of trading, which is expected on Wednesday.

UBS' equities desk launched the discounted equity raising on Monday night. Nic Walker

By then, Costa will have spent the best part of 10 days off the ASX.

And it has been an extremely eventful 10 days.

In that time, the company has downgraded earnings expectations to $98 million for the 2019 financial year on a lease-adjusted EBITDA basis. Its last stated guidance was for $140 million to $153 million, which was later updated to be towards the lower end of that range, while sell-side consensus was $137.9 million according to S &P Capital IQ.

Costa's also had to deal with its banks. Leverage would've soared past three-times – on a net debt to EBITDA-SL basis – given the steep downgrade, while Costa now says it is at 1.14-times on a pro forma basis at June 30.

The big reduction comes as $171 million in shareholder funds are transferred to its banks.

The deal launched after market on Monday, as first reported by Street Talk, and comes after UBS had lined up backers to help in underwriting the offer.

Fundies reckon it is almost impossible to pick where Costa shares will resume trading on Wednesday. Such recapitalisation rights issues are rare. They're normally the domain of the seriously stretched, and some of those, such as Arrium and RCR Tomlinson, that have embarked on such deals in recent years haven't been able to overcome their issues.

The question is whether Debney can convince his shareholders otherwise.
description: Costa Group boss Harry Debney faces a test in his bid to save one of Australia's biggest fruit and vegetable growers.
